main event: On March 2nd, 1949 at 0010 hours, an inspector at AEC Los Alamos observed a light low in the sky traveling rapidly in a horizontal plane from north to south. The object appeared to be self-luminous, covered half of the observer's line of vision in two seconds, and disappeared behind trees.
interesting points: The sighting lasted only two seconds, but the object covered a significant portion of the observer's field of view in that time, indicating very fast speed.
The object exhibited self-luminosity and appeared quite dim and constant in intensity, consistent throughout the brief sighting.
The observer was a guard with the Atomic Energy Security Services, enhancing the credibility of the report.
The weather conditions at the time of sighting included a thin overcast at 20,000 feet, providing context for the atmospheric conditions.
The observation took place at AEC Los Alamos, adding a level of authority to the report due to the nature of the observer's employment.
sighted object: a self-luminous light low in the sky traveling rapidly in a horizontal plane from north to south
witnesses: inspector with the Atomic Energy Security Services
photographs: no photographs included in the report
